oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Don Williams Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Don Williams (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Don Williams; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Don Williams describes the lessons "Learn to Let It Go" teaches about mental health -- (00:34) Biff Collie and Williams discuss the various interpretations of "One Good Well" -- (02:05) "Cryin' Eyes" is associated to a time Williams toured with Emmylou Harris and Waylon Jennings -- (03:30) Collie has Williams discuss the song-writing process while being a traveling musician -- (05:00) Williams tells that he most often is alone -- (05:09) "I've Been Loved By The Best" writer Bob McDill is discussed for his relationship to Williams -- (06:21) Williams and Collie reflect on why Williams chooses not to listen to a song in front of a writer -- (07:59) Williams recalls the first song of McDill's he recorded -- (09:12) Williams states that the most important part of his career has been to stay true to himself -- (11:04) Williams recalls how he feared recording "Broken Heartland" -- (13:03) Williams praises "Just As Long As I Have You" as an encapsulation of his feelings for his wife -- (13:59) Williams recalls meeting his wife at a department store -- (15:03) Collie inquires about what Williams enjoys doing in Hawaii -- (15:43) Williams describes how he discovered "Why Get Up" via his son -- (17:11) Williams touches on his children's musical inclinations -- (18:45) Williams identifies with the message of "Maybe That's All It Takes" -- (20:41) Williams reveals that "We're All the Way" was originally recorded by Eric Clapton; additionally, Collie and Williams discuss how Garth Fundis has been Williams producer for awhile -- (21:41) Collie has Williams describe what a Garden of Stone is from "Flowers Don't Grow (In Gardens of Stone)" -- (22:15) Williams reflects on his relationship with his wife -- (23:48) The inspiration for "If You Love Me, Won't You Love Me Like You Love Me" writer McDill is discussed; Collie and Williams say their goodbyes
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Williams, Don, 1939-; Williams, Don, 1939-2017; Collie, Biff;
